utterances: They'll be paper prototyping, and then I'm hoping to get them to actually build the screens in App Inventor too.

Fantastic.

I've liked it so far, so I feel nobody else I know does this kind of thing.
And I feel cool being a girl and of color doing this kind of thing that I don't really see often, not even in movies.
So I think it's really cool.
The whole point of this is to build an app fast and see if it's something that people want.
So today we're...
UX is a feeling.
It's the feeling that you want people to feel when they visit your app.
My name is Kisha Michelle Richardson.
I'm a senior software engineer at Westfield Labs.
Organizations like this help bring more people into the pipeline just as much as a diversity board at a large corporation.
There should be some form of action because it's interactive.
It's an app.

It's not really an app.
There was nothing like Black Girls CODE in Brooklyn.
I grew up in Bed-Stuy in Crown Heights.
In fact, there were no science-oriented projects.

The biggest takeaway that I'd love them to get is a love for building something with technology, a love for tinkering, a love for maybe one day thinking about pursuing a career in this burgeoning industry.

We actually took a field trip to Google yesterday, and I like to sort of point out to the girls, like, look around.
Do you see people who look like you here?
And they seemed a little shocked to actually, you know, be in a place where you don't really see anyone who looks like you is a culture shock.

Voices from a Black Girls CODE summer camp in San Francisco collected by Eric Westervelt of the NPR Ed team.
In Iraq, the city of Tikrit and the areas around it are at the center of an ongoing battle.
Sunni extremists with the self-proclaimed Islamic State took over the predominantly Sunni area in June.
Now Iraqi security forces and allied militias are trying to drive ISIS out.
Most of these forces are Shiite and backed by Iran, and some have a record of revenge attacks on Sunnis, but NPR's Deborah Amos spoke to local Sunni tribesmen who have unexpectedly joined the Shia.
Ali Al Jabbouri agrees to meet here in northern Iraq a few hours before he heads for the battlefront.
A member of a prominent Iraqi tribe, Jabbouri is also the mayor of a city of 100,000, Al Shargat, now occupied by ISIS militants.
And tomorrow, you are going to change from your suit and...
I am soldier in army - (laughter) my army.
His army is a tribal force, more than a thousand men.
This graying city mayor has reason to fight.
Eighteen of his relatives are dead, including his brother, killed by militants in June.
His city is a victim of ISIS and the map.
Located on a highway between two larger urban centers, ISIS sees Mosul first, then swept down the highway towards Tikrit, grabbing Al Shargat along the way.
ISIS declared Ali Jabbouri's city as part of the so-called Islamic caliphate.
Yes.
My city.
Recently, more militants have showed up as pro-government forces hit Tikrit.
Some ISIS fighters are retreating north.
They left Tikrit and come to Al Shargat - the ISIS.
So that's why you're going back to fight?
Yes.
So that I go to Al Shargat to kill any ISIS.
A decade ago, the Jabbouri tribe fought militants alongside Americans.
Many joined the awakening movement organized by the U.S.
military.
This time, Jabbouri says he's fighting alongside Iran and Iraq's Shiite militias.
It's a surprising alliance considering Jabbouri was once an officer in Saddam Hussein's army fighting against Iran, and many Sunnis are especially wary of their powerful Shiite neighbor.
But times are different, he insists.
Iran is willing to put boots on the ground.
(Through interpreter) Yes, that's right.
I was in the Iraqi army, but you have to know what - when ISIS come, we just need help for anyone - America, Turkey, anyone.
No one help us.
Iran help us, and it's fine.
Iran help us.
No one help us.
America don't help us.
Iran is helping and backs Iraq's Shiite militias, but there's a major snag as pictures of Shiite revenge attacks against Sunnis emerge.
One particularly gruesome image - a Shia militiamen posed with the severed head of an alleged ISIS fighter and posted it on Twitter.
A Human Rights Watch report this week documents looting and burning of civilian homes in Sunni villages.
Washington has warned of funding cuts if the militias aren't reined in.
Analyst Zaid Al Ali says that Baghdad has finally gotten the message.
It seems to be the case now that the government is kind of getting its act together.
The Prime Minister publicly condemned the abuse and warned of severe punishment if it didn't stop.
It's a crucial message for the major battles to come, says Zaid Al Ali, author of ""The Struggle For Iraq's Future."" Sunnis in ISIS-controlled Mosul are all watching what happens in Tikrit.
Well, to the east you will see a very classic Florida subdivision and to the west you see corn fields and lots of agricultural lands that are currently being watered.
And if you would go about two miles northwest of here, you would be at the border of Everglades National Park.
We're standing on the edge of Miami-Dade County's Urban Development Boundary, a line drawn in the 1980's that was intended to be a wall that would contain the areas runaway development.
It was created by a county commission concerned about the cost of building roads, schools and fire stations to serve new communities steadily expanding westward.
It was also seen as a tool to promote good urban planning and to discourage suburban sprawl.
But almost from the moment of its birth, Miami's Urban Development Boundary, the UDB, has been under siege.
At the request of developers, it's been moved by the County Commission more than 50 times in the last two decades.
County Commissioner Joe Martinez says he considers the line as it's currently drawn a joke.
UDB is an imaginary line that was drawn by somebody who had maybe too many scotches that day they did drew the line because it doesn't make sense, and it's not even straight.
No scientific study was ever done to determine the UDB, so I don't put too much stock in that.
Martinez is one of a majority of county commissioners who voted repeatedly to move the boundary to accommodate commercial development.
This week the County Commission will consider a request to once again move the line and approve the biggest project yet, one that would include retail, schools, offices and nearly 7,000 homes.
It's called Parkland, who would cover nearly a 1000 acres, and it's planned by Miami-based Lennar, one of the nation's largest home builders.
Lennar's Ray Milendi(ph) says rather than more sprawl, it represents a chance for Miami to plan how it will grow.
It's a mixed use community where we're creating a community with a sense of place.
We're providing the opportunity for reverse commutes.
There's employment centers.
There's 3,000 well-paying jobs on the site, three schools, we're providing an enormous water treatment facility that would treat and re-use a 100 percent of our waste water.
And you could only do that in a comprehensive manner.
You can't do that on 20, 30 acres.
Lennar and other developers said they look outside the UDB because they can't find suitable land for their projects inside the boundary.
Dawn Sheriffs is with Hold the Line, a group formed to pressure country officials to stop accommodating developers and the push west for the Everglades.
Standing on the proposed site, Sheriffs says there's another reason builders seek land outside the boundary.
Well what we're looking in this project is 961 acres of agriculturally zone land.
What that means is it's a lot cheaper to purchase agriculturally zone land, the lands inside the Urban Development Boundary.
Therefore the profit margin can be higher for a developer.
And it comes at a time when builders in Florida and elsewhere are building few houses and could use a boost to their bottom line.
Milendi doesn't argue that Lennar and other developers involved with the project will see a financial payoff if the Miami-Dade County Commission votes to move the boundary and approve the project.
But he says it requires a big investment from the company and it will be years before Lennar sees a return.
And approval is by no means certain.
Ms.
KATIE SORENSON(ph) (UDB): In Miami-Dade as in the rest of Florida, developers have always ruled.
On Miami-Dade's County Commission, Katie Sorenson has long led the fight to control growth and maintain the Urban Development Boundary.
The solution to Miami's problems of traffic and congestion, she believes, is to build up not out.
We have to get to get to a better form of development and that means doing urban infill, having people live in more compact communities and being able to walk to things.
Lennar says Parkland would be just that: A pedestrian-friendly community that represents the latest in green building and good urban planning.
It's just that to build it, Miami-Dade County needs to redraw its Urban Development Boundary just one more time.
Greg Allen, NPR News, Miami.
From NPR News, this is News & Notes, I'm Farai Chideya.
Maybe your bills are increasing and your paycheck seems to be getting smaller.
And then there are some folks who aren't getting a paycheck at all anymore.
Employers have cut jobs for the sixth straight month, 62,000 in June alone, that's according to the latest U.S.
unemployment report.
So, if you've gotten a pink slip, what do you do?
Author and economist Dr. Julianne Malveaux is here to tell us.
She's also the president of Bennett College.
Hi, Dr. Malveaux.
Hi, Farai, how are you?
I'm good.
But you know, 62,000 jobs in one month.
Let's dissect those numbers a little bit.
So you lost that many jobs, or we did as a country, but unemployment stayed at 5.5 percent.
How can that be?
Well, although we lost jobs, some people left the labor market.
The unemployment rate is a ratio of the number of people who are either working or looking for work, and the number of people who don't have jobs.
So let's say that you haven't had a job for six moths and you're sick of looking.
I mean there's a measurement for looking, which is how often you're looking, what you're doing, you're like forget it.
It's summer I'm just going to just drop out of the labor market.
Or can't find a job, your skill set doesn't match what you need, I'm going back to school.
Or you're not counted anymore as unemployed.
You want a job but you're not counted as unemployed.
So there are a category of people called discouraged workers, people who would look for work if they thought they could find jobs and there are nearly 1.6 million people in that category.
Well, it looks like manufacturing and retail are losing jobs, and government and healthcare are adding jobs.
But if you think you might lose your job, how do you get prepared for that?
Well first of all people need to understand that - and I'm not - I know that everyone thinks about this now with the unemployment rate, but make sure you understand the climate of where you work.
If you're working at one of the - any company but certainly one that's publicly traded, know what the stock is looking like, know what the buzz is.
Pay attention to corporate communications, and keep your options open.
If you think that you are vulnerable for layoffs, start looking, get those resumes out there, or at least get it polished up.
So the falsity of the speech there is as critical as the connection between the speech and the harm.
It is a tough bicycle ride today, in the Tour de France.
The fifteenth stage, up an infamous mountain, L'Alpe d'Huez.
The cyclists climbed almost 3,700 feet of switchback turns to the very top, and Frank Schleck of Luxembourg won the stage.
But the American, Floyd Landis, has regained the yellow jersey as the overall leader.
Phil Liggit is covering every kilometer of the tour for OLN television, welcome Mr. Liggit.
Lovely to speak to you.
